msg: Y
It was a Paris daily tabloid newspaper full of sex, scandal and sports results.
It was a thin, supple twig of hazel.
Y
The towel was soaked through with water.
The towel had dried out but was still damp.
The towel had dried out and was barely damp.
It was a key ring bearing one large brass key and a tag which read 'Hotel Ubu'.
It was the bright red ball I'd got from the juggler.
The statuette looked pretty sorry for itself after its fall; chipped with both arms broken off.
The nose was hollow. Printed on the inside were the words: `La Risée du Monde, Paris'.
It was a bright red plastic nose, part of a clown's costume.
It was hard to believe it was the same chalice. Now the light gleamed off its perfect surface.
Fifty bucks! In the States I'd have thought of it as a good night out. Here in Marib it represented hard currency.
It was Nico's photograph of the man we suspected of killing Plantard.
On the key ring was a big, old key that looked like it might fit the excavation door.
Y
Now I'd substituted the fake key for the excavation key. It looked okay but felt false.
It was a short piece of wire, twisted into a rough circle.
It was a large blue gemstone.
The greasepaint had worked magic. Now it looked like aged marble instead of cheap plaster.
The stick I'd broken off was surprisingly hard and inflexible.
Y
Y
Y
It was the card I'd found in the hotel bedroom. It read 'Thomas Moerlin, Grüber Electronics Corporation'.
It was a metal rod with a handle at one end and a short crosspiece at the other.
It was the ancient manuscript which Khan had stolen from Plantard.
The matchbook bore a pattern of swirling color and the words: `Club Alamut'.
It was the scrap of material I'd found in the sewer.
I was now in possession of the Patented Stobbart Stick-Towel! If I could only think of a use for it...
It was a handful of plaster left in the castle by Peagram's archaeology team.
It was a device used for measuring people's blood pressure.
The tickets were two standard returns from London to Stirling in Scotland.
Y
Y
It was the key to the club toilet.
Y
Y
Y
Y
The chalice from the mausoleum was obviously of superior workmanship but grimy and tarnished.
It was the soggy tissue I'd found in the sewers.
Y
It was the short length of chain I'd taken from the toilet of the Club Alamut.
It was a length of coarse grey towelling from the toilet of the Club Alamut.
It was a simple but elegant tripod made of metal with traces of colored enamel still visible in places.
Y
It was the roller towel from the club washroom, now cut in half along its length by Ultar.
Y
The tissue was pretty charred but the greasepaint had done most of the burning.
The cog was mounted on a short, slim spindle.
The cog was one of those objects I wished I hadn't carried in my pocket.
Y
Y
It was a black plastic pen top.
The pipe could have been anything from fifty to several hundred years old...
It was the barman's flashlight.
No point in phoning that guy again...
Y
Y
I made an impression of the big key in the cake of soap.
Y
Y
Uh... no.
Hmm... Maybe not.
Hmm... No way.
Uh... That's not a good idea.
It was a rectangle of towelling, printed with the words: `Na Gopaleen's stout builds body!'
It was the Spanish Bible I'd borrowed from the mausoleum.
The keyring contained the keys to the washroom and the excavation.
It was the key to the excavation.
It was my plaster copy of the excavation key. Trouble was, it looked like plaster and it felt like plaster.
The plaster key had soaked up the paint nicely and now looked pretty convincing. Still felt like plaster, though.
It was the `Shake 'n Shock' buzzer I'd been given by the man in the costume shop.
The card read: Augustin Rosso, and gave an address to the south of the Montparnasse Cemetery.
It was the bar of soap I'd stolen from the washroom of the excavation site.
The bar of soap had the imprint of a key in it.
I had filled the key's imprint in the soap with dry plaster.
It was a smooth, intricately carved piece of stone that had been concealed inside the great candle.
It was a short handled brush.
It was the lens that I'd found on Klausner's body.
The mirror from Lopez's utility room. Yep, I was still looking great.
It was the handle from the church tower's winding mechanism. It had cog teeth mounted near its base.
It was an old coin.
With a flourish, I tied the end of the towel to the stick with a textbook reef knot.
Quickly and without fuss I swapped the fake key for the real thing.
I carefully sprinkled the plaster into the soap mold I'd made of the key.
The plaster seemed to soak up the greasepaint until it began to look like stone.
Paris in the Fall; the last months of the year and the end of the millennium.
The city holds many memories for me: of cafés, of music, of love... and of death.
As I picked myself up all I could hear was the ceaseless drone of traffic.
Life went on around me, but the explosion was to change my life forever...
The Sergeant was a scrawny man in his fifties who resembled a constipated chicken.
The girl presented a confident but sullen mask to the world, an expression more suited to the face of a delinquent youth.
Nicole struck me as being a typical Parisian woman: attractive, sensuous even, but with an alarming taste in clothes.
The leading article referred to the visit of a Nobel prize winner from some unprounceable Eastern European State.
That was the only news story: the rest was rumor, gossip and sensationalism.
Then I noticed the writing at the foot of the page...
It read: `Salah-eh Dinn, thirteen forty-five.'
The table had been overturned by the explosion.
It was an iron lamp post.
I considered climbing the lamp post, but it wasn't going to shed any light on the affair.
I contemplated crawling under the umbrella and pretending none of this had ever happened...
The blast had blown out the glass leaving a gaping hole.
I examined the jagged glass remaining in the window. It was broken all right.
I considered straightening the table, but I figured it best not to disturb the evidence.
The umbrella had protected me from the bomb blast, but it was of no use to me now.
Wrapped around the lamppost was a newspaper.
It was a stack of cardboard boxes which had once contained bottles of wine.
I examined the boxes closely. They were damp and smelly, and decidedly empty.
It was a plastic crate.
There was nothing of interest...
The drainpipe looked as if it would bear my weight...
The drainpipe hung limp and useless.
I took a deep breath and prepared to climb the drainpipe...
I guess the clown hadn't escaped over the rooftops.
I decided I'd had enough of messing with that drainpipe.
It was a battered old trash can...
I wondered what else lurked in the depths of that trash can...
It smelled like someone had dumped a truckload of fish in a locker room on a hot summer afternoon.
I'd had it with sticking my nose into French trash cans...
It was an iron cover concealing the entrance to a drain or sewer...
It was a heavy cast-iron cover.
I tried to lift the cover with my fingers, but couldn't gain any leverage.
The cover was too heavy and awkward to lift with my bare hands.
The window was protected by stout looking iron bars.
The bars didn't shift an inch.
I lifted the cover to reveal what smelt like the entrance to a sewer.
The pretty young waitress was unconscious.
The waitress was clearly suffering from shock...
It was the body of the old man.
It was hard to believe I'd seen him alive only minutes before...
The sight of the dead guy's staring eyes turned my knees to jelly...
I tried not to meet his stare as I searched the dead man's pockets.
No wallet, no papers, no credit cards. The guy's past was a blank page.
I checked his pockets. Nothing.
A mysteriously undamaged bottle of spirits stood on the bar.
Æ
Oh, my head. Never again!
How much vodka did I drink? No, don't tell me!
Æ
George Stobbart, ma'am!
Oh... American?
She asked the question quite innocently, but I could sense her reserve.
It was something which seemed to afflict all Europeans...
You look like you could use a little help...
I could use a little drink!
I feel sick, dizzy, and bruised - and I don't even remember the party!
Just relax and take it easy. You've been knocked out...
You don't say! What happened?
There's been an explosion. You should try not to move.
Are you a doctor?
Æ
Æ
Only one of the most brilliant medical minds on this planet.
He taught me everything I know about medicine.
No, but I used to play hospitals when I was a kid...
Can you remember anything at all?
Non. I need a drink. Pour me a brandy.
Is that straight, or with ice?
Just give me the bottle with a teat on it.
I guess a little drop won't hurt.
Æ
She knocked back the brandy as if it was water.
I was glad I wasn't picking up the check!
You could be in shock. No alcohol.
Æ
What about the old man - is he dead?
I think he might be.
Yes, he is.
Ah, mon Dieu!
Æ
That was different - she was family.
Has he... gone stiff?
I shouldn't think so. He's only been dead a few minutes.
Of course not.
I didn't want an hysterical French girl on my hands - at least, not right now...
I don't know. I haven't looked at him yet.
Some doctor! I am glad I am not one of your patients, m'sieur.
Perhaps you should...
She didn't respond. If I wanted another cappuccino, I'd have to serve myself.
Hey, wake up!
Hey!
Huh?
Do you remember what happened when the clown entered?
I remember that horrible tune he played all right!
It was like a funeral dirge!
I'd never liked accordion music, either.
Did the clown speak to the old man?
No - he just laughed at him.
Æ
Did the old man try to stop the clown?
Oh, he didn't have a chance.
Æ
That's it. That's all I can remember.
Did you see what the old man had in his briefcase?
No. He didn't open it.
What did the old man do when the clown snatched his briefcase?
Nothing. He just sat there, like he was frozen.
Did you know the old man?
No, m'sieur, I never saw him before.
How did the old man behave?
Well... agitated. He kept looking about him - at the door, at his watch...
As if he was waiting for someone?
Yes, I suppose so. He was worried about something, that's for sure.
If you ask me, he was having an affair.
He had that look about him... like a guilty husband.
Æ
I'm going to look around for evidence...
Did this newspaper belong to the old gentleman?
I don't know.
Someone has scribbled a note on it.
It reads: `Salah-ed-Din, thirteen forty-five.'
Does that mean anything to you?
Non, m'sieur, nothing.
About this newspaper...
I told you - it means nothing to me.
What a mess! This bombing is an outrage, is it not?
Stop that, m'sieur!
Stop holding your breath at once!
Has it occurred to you that he may be dead, Moue...?
Oui, m'sieur, but I prefer to look on the bright side...
Besides, I recall a case where the killer escaped by feigning death!
However, in this case the man is quite dead.
Clearly the killer knew of his presence and...
How many times have I warned you about premature extrapolation?
All we know is that he is dead.
It seemed reasonable to assume...
A great detective assumes nothing. Take Maigret for instance...
B... but he was a fictitious character, monsieur!
Why, he was no more real than... than Poirot or Tintin!
That's different, Moue - they were comedy Belgians.
Anyway, it is unlikely that even you will learn much from talking to the dead.
Examine the girl, and take her statement... if you can.
I doubt if she is in a fit state for questioning, m'sieur.
It smells to me as if she has been drinking!
As I feared. We have stumbled upon a den of iniquity, Moue.
Leave her to me, sir - I am used to handling drunken women.
Æ
Et maintenant, to business!
Your name, please?
George Stobbart. I'm from California.
Æ
Travel. I'm touring Europe.
You chose well. The city is most beautiful at this time of year, non?
Uh... yeah, I guess so - apart from the bomb blasts!
Were you in the vicinity of the café at the time of the explosion?
Æ
I was lucky I wasn't killed!
The Inspector passed over my remark with no reaction...
Did you see the deceased enter the café?
Yes, I did.
Was he alone?
Uh... yeah.
And did he say anything to you?
No. He was more interested in the waitress.
No.
Did you see anyone else in the café?
Yeah, there was a guy dressed as a clown.
He was carrying an accordion.
An accordion?
Bon. The picture is forming in my mind...
And it is not a pretty one!
I'm sorry, Inspector, I didn't.
It never ceases to amaze me how unobservant the public can be!
Is the girl all right, Moue?
She'll live...
If she survives the hangover.
She says the killer was disguised as a clown.
A circus clown? Did you see him, m'sieur?
Oh, yeah! Now you come to mention it, there WAS a clown.
I didn't think much of it at the time. After all, this is Paris...
I see you come well armored with preconception.
Let us hope that your sheath does not turn out to be your shroud.
I told you - I didn't see a thing.
So! Be warned that I, Augustin Rosso, never rest until I reach the truth.
You are my winkle, m'sieur, and I'm not afraid to use the pin.
She says the American claimed to be a doctor.
He forced her to drink the brandy...
I can explain everything!
Can you, m'sieur?
Almost everything.
She confirms the doctor's statement.
Oui? You did not tell me you were a doctor, m'sieur.
Uh, no. That's right. I didn't think it was relevant.
She confirms the American's statement.
A clown with an accordion, no doubt an elaborate and eccentric disguise.
Very well.
She doesn't remember seeing a clown, m'sieur.
That's odd, don't you think, m'sieur?
Who am I to believe, I wonder?
Eh bien. I have heard enough.
What do you mean?
I am satisfied that you know nothing. You may leave.
I hope this little incident does not spoil the rest of your vacation...
Enjoy your vacation, Doctor Stobbart...
What about my personal safety? Can't you at least give me some advice?
What can I say? Stay alert, and look out for suspicious characters...
And don't cross the road until the little man shows green.
Great advice.
I honestly believe you are in no danger, m'sieur.
Should you remember anything of importance, please contact me.
My card...
Thanks.
That is all. You may go.
There's not much to go on, m'sieur...
On the surface, no. But what lurks inside the subconscious?
If the door can only be opened...
Are you serious, m'sieur? I thought your interest in psychic detection was purely academic...
Academic? You are about to witness a scientific breakthrough!
Æ
Æ
I needed a stiff drink, but I hated the taste of brandy.
What is your name, cheri?
Who is he?
Ah! That is better.
Then he grabbed the old guy's briefcase and ran out of the door.
The clown dropped his accordion and ran out of the door.
Stay here, madamoiselle.
I do not doubt that for one moment...
Yeah. I was sitting out on the sidewalk.
Okay - you're the doctor.
I've never seen a real live corpse before, except for grande-maman.
And what brings you to Paris, M'sieur Stobbart?
Æ
Yes, I am. I studied under Doctor Benton.
It was a huge and weighty looking engineers' telephone.
It was a tent made out of plastic sheeting.
There was nothing inside the tent except a large toolbox.
It was a battered metal toolbox.
I found a T-shaped tool in the box. I didn't know what it was, but it looked useful...
I'd found just what I wanted - a tool for lifting manhole covers.
The toolbox didn't contain anything else I needed.
Set into the huge gate was a smaller access door.
The door was securely locked.
No reply. The old concierge must have been busy...
Don't touch that phone!
Sorry...
Hé! Clear off!
Hé, what did I tell you?
Don't touch!
Okay, already!
Hé, stop that! Get away from there!
What d'you think you're doing?
I was... admiring your toolbox.
Ah, oui? Had a good look, have you?
I'm warning you - if you touch it I'll crack your nut!
Okay! I get your point...
He hadn't heard me...
Hi.
You're the guy who gave me the tip, aren't you?
Huh?
The racehorse - Salah-eh Dinn.
Oh, yeah. But...
I put every franc I had on that horse.
Listen, I...
My life-time savings, next month's rent - everything.
Oh, god.
She won by three lengths!
I'm a rich man!
Call me Lucky George, the punter's friend...
So how come you're still here?
Oh, I'm not going to let my new-found wealth change me, not one bit.
I've bought this hole, fittings and all.
Now I can come and go as I please.
No more clocking on or completion schedules...
No foreman breathing down my neck...
Thanks to you, I've found paradise.
Hey, you!
Hi! Can you spare a few minutes?
I thought you'd been arrested?
No. It was a misunderstanding.
When he pulled that gun - cah! - I thought that was it.
Those automatics pack quite a punch, you know.
He made a mistake. He thought I was a terrorist.
You? A terrorist? Ha!
He was only doing his duty, I guess.
What do you want now?
Did you see a clown come by this way?
A clown? Like in a circus?
Yeah. With make-up and a big red nose.
Ho! Those guys are funny, aren't they?
Not in my experience.
I love the circus - especially the horses.
You haven't answered my question.
Have you seen a clown?
You think I've got time to watch everyone who passes by?
Some of us have to work for a living.
Look, I know you're busy, but surely you'd have noticed a clown?
I told you already, I didn't see a thing!
He was wearing multicolored baggy trousers and make-up!
He'd be a poor sort of clown if he didn't...
Listen - I have to find that clown. He's a killer.
Why would I want to help the cops?
Community spirit. Together we can combat crime and stuff.
Say, who are you anyhow? A cop?
No, of course not. Do I look like a cop?
Non, but you act like one, sticking your nose in where it's not wanted...
I guess not.
How do you know this guy's a killer? Did you see him in action?
I wondered what that bang was...! Any bodies?
Yeah. An old man was killed.
Merde! I didn't think it was that serious. What about the waitress?
Oh, she's fine.
Thank the saints!
The clown killed the old man?
That's right. Blew him up with a bomb concealed in his squeeze-box.
Merde! But why did he go to the bother of dressing up like a clown?
Who can unravel the tangled logic of a killer's mind?
I guess it's some deep-seated psychological need - or just plain showmanship.
Did you see an old guy with a briefcase?
Oui. Silly old coot! D'you know what he said to me?
Work fascinates me, he says. I could watch it all day.
Quelle bitte! I could have knocked his block off!
Did you recognize the old man?
Non. Should I have done? Was he a celebrity?
No, but I guess he is now.
His name was Plantard.
Was? He's dead, then?
Was he the one who died in the café?
Yeah.
That's too bad.
Now I wish I hadn't called him what I did.
If only I could turn back the clock! If only I'd been more tolerant!
Regret and remorse are strange emotions...
They really bring out the hammiest actors in people.
What's in the toolbox?
What's in the toolbox! As if you didn't know!
What's the big deal about tools, anyhow?
They're cool. Tools are Civilization!
You don't say?
That's right. Tools are what distinguish us from other animals.
Who are you calling an animal? I've met your sort before!
I've a good mind to knock your block off!
What kind of tools d'you keep in your box?
Hein? You really ARE interested in tools?
Sure! Like I said - tools are...
Yeah - civilization - so you keep saying.
So - are you going to show them to me?
Am I... why, you...!
Aw, c'mon! Just a little peek?
I've got work to do. Find someone else to bother.
Do you have a tool for lifting manhole covers?
As it happens, I do.
Cool! Lend it to me - just for a few minutes!
Non.
Aw, c'mon...
Non! Get your own.
Let me explain what I'm going to do with your manhole-lifting tool...
Let me explain what I'm going to do with my pick.
Oh - hey! Forget it. I'll come back when you're in a better mood.
It doesn't get any better than this!
I gotta go.
Don't let me keep you...
Would you like to read my newspaper?
I haven't got time to read that! Can't you see I'm busy?
You could read it on your lunch break...
Ten minutes is all I get, and if my boss had his way, I wouldn't get that!
He'd have me on a drip so I didn't have to stop to eat!
Oh, take the newspaper and quit complaining.
Pah! Look at this! Damned bleeding-heart liberals!
Tchah! Save the dolphins? Catch them and eat them, I say!
All that fuss over a bunch of fish!
Now that's more like it! Look at the size of those!
Like champagne bottle corks, non?
AH! What's this? Salah-eh Dinn - running in the Prix de l'Arc de Triomphe!
It's a race horse?
A horse? A legend! Bucephalus reborn, mon ami!
Like a streak of lightning, she is!
Do me a favor won't you? Keep an eye on my hole...
I'm off to put some money on that nag!
What about your toolbox?
Stuff it! Help yourself!
Does this matchbook mean anything to you?
No, it doesn't.
Does the name Moerlin mean anything to you?
No, nothing.
What do you make of this clown's nose?
It would be more amusing if you were wearing it.
Do you recognize the man in this photograph?
No, I don't.
Do you recognize this tissue?
Certainly not!
I borrowed this tool from you while you were gone...
Keep it! I can afford to buy a new set now.
Would you like to shake hands with me?
No, I wouldn't.
One of the real pleasures of being rich is not having to be polite.
Take a look at this...
You told me you weren't a cop!
Aie! You're a cop?
Don't shout about it. I'm working under cover.
Who are you looking for?
That's confidential.
Check out my card...
I've seen it already.
Freeze! Hold it right there!
Woah - don't shoot! I'm innocent! I'm an American!
Can't make up your mind, huh?
I demand to see the American Consul!
Drop your weapons and get down on the ground!
Put that thing away, Sergeant Moue.
I apologize, m'sieur, but I cannot permit you to leave.
Am I under arrest?
Ah, non! I would simply like to ask you some questions.
En avant - to the café! Marche!
The muscular workman wore a morose expression, like a silent warning to leave him to get on with his job...
I'm getting a mushy feeling in my chest, but not half as mushy as your head.
Didn't you hear the explosion? The café was blown up!
Looking down your nose at me because I'm working class, huh?
It looked like some kind of antiquated invalid carriage - with passenger seats.
The door was locked.
The door led to the apartment of the blustering old concierge.
It was a small access door set into the wooden gate.
The fountain had probably been attractive at one time, but now it looked like an old stained urinal.
It was the ladder leading back up to the alley.
It was a shiny red plastic ball, sat incongruously on the slippery, green-slimed floor.
As I picked up the plastic ball, I realized it was intended to be worn.
It was the clown's red nose.
The rusty ladder led back up to the daylight.
The railing was put there for a simple reason - to stop people getting past. It worked.
The rusty railing prevented me from passing.
I took hold of the scrap of material and unsnagged it from the spike.
It was a small scrap of cloth, caught on the rusting spike.
It was a soggy, crumpled paper tissue.
I scooped up the sodden tissue. It was cold and greasy like breakfast leftovers.
The woman was doing something with a pair of needles that couldn't be described as knitting.
ª
The door was shabby and in need of a coat of paint.
I couldn't imagine the Collard woman living here.
It was the door to Nico's apartment.
I pushed against the door, but it seemed to be locked.
Remembering the flower seller's advice, I pushed the door gently just above the lock...
They were lilies, or tulips - some kinda flowers, anyhow.
Pretty, I guess, if you like that sort of thing.
Me, I couldn't see the point of buying something that was already half-dead.
The last of the summer blooms on the flower stall were a reminder of the coming fall...
I inhaled deeply, expecting to experience the scent of the flowers. What I got was traffic fumes.
The shop window featured a display of gowns and women's stuff.
It wasn't the style of the clothes in the shop that caught my eye but the prices.
The same amount of money would feed a starving family for the rest of their lives.
I guess people who buy that kinda stuff don't have a problem with their consciences.
ª
The vacant shop was sealed with a steel blind.
There was no way of lifting the securely locked blind.
It was a foodstore, selling fruit and vegetables.
I glanced without much interest at the fruit. It was dusty, shrivelled and tired looking.
Oh hi!
She didn't hear me...
Bonjour, m'sieur!
Would you like me to foretell your future?
Oh... no, thanks.
I'm very good, and it only takes a minute!
Thanks all the same, but I'm not superstitious.
Besides, if it only takes a minute, that's not much of a future to look forward to...
ª
ª
Maybe not yet... but I see your paths entwined in the future.
I doubt it.
Hallo, my handsome friend.
I've changed my mind. Will you tell my fortune?
You're going on a long journey.
My, oh my. What a surprise.
Can you tell me anything I don't already know?
Ten francs please, my dear.
ª
Please yourself.
How does this fortune telling routine work?
If I knew that I wouldn't be selling flowers for a living.
Haven't you ever wondered why you were blessed with the gift?
Well, it's a bit like satellite television I suppose.
Some of us are born with a built-in receiver dish.
I just happen to be one of the lucky ones.
Can you really foretell the future?
Only time will tell, m'sieur!
The strange thing is, I can't seem to see myself in the future.
Other people - I have no problem.
But when I try to see what might happen to me - nothing!
That must be scarey.
Maybe. I figure it's a kind of natural safety mechanism.
Either that, or I don't have a future.
Do you know a young woman called Nicole Collard?
Yes, I do!
She lives upstairs from me, in the apartment block across the street.
I tried the door, but it's locked.
You know, I've told the landlord about that a million times!
It is the damp. That whole building is like a sponge!
It sucks up the moisture from god knows where.
You mean the door is stuck because it's swollen?
That is correct. There is an art to opening it.
Don't shove it hard - just give it a gentle nudge above the lock!
Thanks for the advice...
The door isn't locked, but you'll need to give it a gentle nudge.
It sticks, you see - because of the damp.
The landlord said he'd fix it before winter sets in.
He's been saying that for three years.
How long has Mademoiselle Collard lived here?
A few months. She's in for a shock when the cold weather comes.
Drafty windows, insufficient heating - it's a struggle to keep warm.
The only reason I stay is because the rent is cheap.
Your young lady - she deserves better.
I thought Mademoiselle Collard was a successful photographer...
Not as successful as she makes out, for all her fine clothes.
Oh, I've heard her crying herself to sleep at night.
That's awful.
Now don't you let on that I've told you.
She's proud, that one - too proud, if you ask me.
Have you seen anyone out here, watching Mademoiselle Collard's apartment?
Yes, I have. A strange man, tall and thin as a broomstick.
He kept his face hidden, but I saw his eyes, peering from evil little slits.
How was he dressed?
A long brown raincoat, with a hat.
Like Humphrey Bogart?
Yes, but he didn't have Bogart's charisma.
Besides, this guy looked like he needed a toilet...
You never saw Bogart clenching his buttocks like that!
Are the flowers for sale?
Oui, msieur.
Okay, I'll take a bunch of those white ones.
I wouldn't do that if I was you.
No?
They are lilies, m'sieur.
Some people associate them with death...
Yikes! Thanks for telling me.
What other flowers do you have?
Dahlias?
What do they signify?
Insecurity.

Genghis Khan - the legendary Mongol barbarian chieftain?
No, darling - Kevin.
Kevin Khan? I never heard of him.
I'd be most surprised if you had, darling. He's a pharmacist in Hemel Hempstead.
Organizes fund raising for the Rotarians. Lovely man.
Does he have a scar on his cheek?
I really wouldn't know, sweetie.
The man you know as Moerlin is a fake.
What do you mean, sweetie?
He's a murderer. He also uses the name `Khan'
I am shocked, Mister Stobbart. Shaken!
I took him to be a gentleman, a man of honor...
Do you know, I'd rather like to assist you in stitching him up!
When did you last see Moerlin?
It was no more than an hour ago...
He came downstairs and spoke to that clerk chappie.
Something passed hands - I couldn't see what, exactly.
A briefcase?
No - smaller than that. A bundle of papers, perhaps.
The clerk put it in the hotel safe, and Moerlin went out.
Are you sure you saw Moerlin putting documents in the safe?
Yes, darling. Positive.
I wonder what they were?
Obviously something of great importance.
Yeah. I'd sure like to get my hands on whatever it is.
I'll bet they had something to do with Plantard's briefcase...
Has Moerlin returned to the hotel?
No, he hasn't. Are you going to search his room?
If I could get in there I would.
And that's why you want the key?
Yes, ma'am.
Do you know anything about history, ma'am?
Why, George - I am a living link with the past!
Don't be too hard on yourself, Lady Piermont. You're wearing well.
I was referring to my family tree, darling.
I wondered if you'd ever heard of the Knights Templar?
Oh, yes. Of course, none of the Piermonts ever considered joining them.
Chastity, poverty and piety weren't exactly our strong points, I'm glad to say.
My grandfather once led a cavalry charge on a local temperance meeting.
Mind you, that was more to do with his personal dislike of General Booth...
I have to go, ma'am.
Do you know what this is?
At a guess, I'd say it was a clown's nose.
That's right. It was worn as a disguise by a vicious killer.
That's him.
Good heavens! Are you trying to alarm me?
It's true. He uses the name Khan.
I've never heard of the man.
Did I show you this false nose?
Yes, you did.
Do you recognize the man in this photograph?
My god! It's him. That's Moerlin!
She represented everything I loved about the English. The lady was totally deranged.
Merlin? You mean King Arthur's wizard?
Good heavens, no. M'sieur Moerlin is a fellow guest.
He's the man I've been telling you about!
That's the man who spurned me!
Did I show you this photograph?
Yes, darling.
Would you like to keep Moerlin's pass as a memento?
No, darling. My broken heart is reminder enough...
I found this pass in Moerlin's room...
So - that deceitful little man is passing himself off as an electrician, is he?
Uh-huh. This guy probably has a million faces...
I showed the pass to the clerk, hoping he'd give me Moerlin's papers...
...but he wouldn't buy it. He's too scared.
I'll give him something to be scared of!
Follow me, George!
Did you place a package from Moerlin in the hotel safe?
I did, madame.
And did my friend here show you Moerlin's identification?
Indeed he did, but...
What's the problem?
He isn't Moerlin.
A mere academic detail. Give him the package.
But - that is against the law!
I happen to be a Justice of the Peace, you silly man.
I am the Law!
If he tries anything - shoot him, George.
My pleasure, Lady Piermont.
One moment, please.
You know, I haven't enjoyed myself this much since Greenham Common!
Voila, m'sieur. Le manuscrit du Monsieur Moerlin.
Thanks.
The clerk had given me a tightly rolled sheet of parchment.
I decided not to unroll it until I was safely back in Nico's apartment...
This is what Moerlin was so keen to hide...
Really? All that fuss for a sample of wallpaper?
If I was you, I'd keep it well out of sight until you're clear of this place.
That's exactly what I was thinking.
I could roll it up and put it down my pants...
No, no - that won't do at all.
You'd attract far too much attention.
Thanks for helping me get the manuscript, Lady Piermont.
Anytime, my dear.
Can you think of any use for this tool, ma'am?
I can think of someone I'd like to use it on!
I found this matchbook in Moerlin's bedroom...
It came from the Club Alamut.
It might be useful to find out if that club is in Paris, George.
Would you care to shake my hand, ma'am?
Now, George - there's no need to be so formal.
Does the name on this card mean anything to you?
Augustin Rosso? No, dear - nothing.
It conjures up the image of a Gauloise-smoking, Absinthe-drinking French policeman.
I'm sure the real Inspector Rosso is nowhere near so romantic...
I think you'd be surprised.
Does this tissue mean anything to you?
Good god, no!
I just thought the smell might be familiar...
Please, darling - put it away.
I'm no shrinking violet, but that object makes me feel quite queasy!
Please, darling - not that again!
This is the key to room twenty-one...
That's next to the room taken by that rotten Moerlin, isn't it?
Yes, and it's vacant.
Really? How convenient...
Uh... yeah.
Do you want this key?
No, thank you, darling.
She had all the qualities of Bodicea, Elizabeth the First and Margaret Thatcher rolled into one...
I figured the lady at the keys wouldn't appreciate a duet with a musical illiterate like me...
When people book into an hotel, they leave their morals at home, non?
No, not a real gorilla - it was a guy who LOOKED like a gorilla.
I'm looking for a man who dresses like a clown.
Uh... Like what?

Not spécialement. The room is vacant.
Aw, forget it.
Oh. Well, this guy is dead, anyhow.
I don't know about that. Few of my ancestors were honest; not even to God.
Boy! Check my jewelry hasn't been stolen.
That gangster I told you about - he went through my pockets just now!
I'm only familiar with one person named Khan.
Ah! Moerlin, perchance?
I don't know what I would have done without you, Lady Piermont.
How satisfying. An Anglo-American alliance that actually worked!
It's some kind of manuscript, and it looks to be very old.
We met as tourists, and I want to keep it that way, despite the enormous social gulf between us.
I just couldn't bring myself to use the buzzer on this dear lady...
Maybe it was my imagination, but I had an uncomfortable feeling about this situation.
Excuse me - didn't I see your picture in the newspaper?
The sign on the door read twenty-one.
Maybe it wasn't the right room, but this was the right key...
The sign on the door read twenty-two.
If the tailor's description was correct, this was the killer's room.
The door was locked...
It wasn't the right key for the door...
Room number twenty-three...
A small cabinet stood beside the bed.
The cabinet was empty, but it smelt of onions. No kidding, it really did.
It was a massive mahogany wardrobe...
There was nothing in the wardrobe apart from a vague lingering smell of camphor.
The window looked out over a narrow alley surrounded by high walls.
I resisted a childish desire to toss things from a height.
I knew this was no way to treat an ancient manuscript.
I couldn't let it fall into the hands of the goons waiting outside, though.
The cobbles of the alleyway looked very distant and very hard.
If I wanted my shins sticking out of my shoulders, I could've jumped.
Mama Stobbart didn't raise no suicidal fools, though.
It was the rolled-up manuscript, waiting to be retrieved.
I figured it was best for me to return to the street before attempting to pick up the manuscript.
The bed was several times larger than the narrow cot I'd been given at the place I was staying.
The bed was freshly made, and the crisp white sheets told me nothing about the killer's habits....
It was the battered leather briefcase I'd seen Plantard carrying just before he died...
I searched the interior of the briefcase but, as I'd half expected, it was empty.
The cabinet had no drawers, just a single door.
The assassin had been too smart to leave incriminating evidence beside his bed...
The door led back into the hall.
I had the kind of feeling in my stomach that would usually send me running to the bathroom.
The pants were newly laundered and pressed with immaculate creases.
There was nothing in the pockets of the pants.
The pants matched the jacket which the killer had lost in Paris...
I couldn't believe my luck when I found two items in the pockets of the pants.
The first was an ordinary matchbook. No matches; no clues.
The second was a pass card which read: `Thomas Moerlin, Grüber Electronics Corporation'.
There was nothing else in the pockets of the killer's pants.
The closet was a solid, impressive piece of antique furniture.
The interior of the closet was large enough for me to climb right in...
The window didn't provide a very good view, but it gave me a means of escape...
The policeman was not much older than me. His face wore an expression of intense concentration.
It was Rosso's sidekick: Sergeant Moue.
It was a public telephone...
Hi there.
Bonjour.
Ah! M'sieur Hardy, non?
Stobbart. George Stobbart.
Hi! It's me again.
Again?
Yes. I spoke to you... earlier.
But of course. It is M'sieur Hardy.
Stobbart. George Stobbart.
Ah, oui. Can I help you?
Excuse me...
Not so fast! I'd like your personal details, please.
Huh? What for?
In the event of an accident.
It would help us to know where to send the body.
Look - is this really necessary? I came in here to talk to Rosso.
Ah! Why did you not say!
Is Sergeant Moue available?
What? You want to speak to him?
Yes, please.
I cannot recall the last time someone asked to speak to Moue.
No-one ever speaks to him, not even his kids.
Eh bien - he is not here, m'sieur. He is with Inspecteur Rosso.
Like Laurel and Keaton, non, m'sieur...?
Hardy. Oliver Norville Hardy.
Where's Sergeant Moue?
Sergeant... Moue?
You haven't heard?
Heard what? Has something happened to him?
Moue is dead.
You're kidding.
Non, m'sieur.
That's... how? Why?
The death of a policeman never comes as a surprise, but always as a shock.
But - Sergeant Moue? He was so...
I know, I know.
He was as flexible as a riot baton, yet his heart was as warm as...
...a freshly extracted urine sample.
May I see Inspector Rosso?
He's not here.
But...
Do you wish to leave a message for him?
I have a choice of blue or black pens.
I'd recommend the blue for a less formal communication.
I'd prefer to talk to him in person.
As you wish, m'sieur.
I'm sorry, but he gave me orders not to disturb him, m'sieur.
Do you know anything about Rosso's psychic techniques?
I cannot comment on my superior's methods.
All I will say is that Inspecteur Rosso has an impressive record.
He's a good detective?
One of the best. He's a man of honor with a fine sense of duty.
You wouldn't say he was a screwball?
Not to his face, m'sieur.
How is Rosso taking the news of Moue's death?
Very well, considering.
Apparently, Moue is quite cheerful, if a little disorientated.
Rosso has been talking to him?
So he says.
Have you had any reports concerning a suspicious clown?
Why, yes! There was a fracas only this morning - three arrests for public disorder!
And you say there was a clown involved?
A clown and a particularly offensive piece of sculpture - with balloons.
Are you in any way involved with the reprobate, m'sieur?
No, not me.
It doesn't matter...
Thanks for your help, officer.
What do you make of this?
It's a juggler's ball.
Have you heard of a guy named Moerlin?
No, m'sieur.
Are you familiar with the Club Alamut?
No, m'sieur.
Do you know what this powder is?
It looks like plaster, m'sieur.
Do you know what this device is used for?
Certainly, m'sieur. It is for measuring the pressure of the blood.
This tripod is over five hundred years old...
Remarkable, m'sieur, but hardly police business.
Can you tell me anything about this gem?
Me? No, m'sieur.
What do you think this lens could be used for?
Hard to say, m'sieur.
Do you know anything about medieval communion cups?
No, m'sieur. I was a duffer at school when it came to history.
I found this scrap of material in the sewer...
Vraiment?
It was probably torn from the clothes of a psychotic killer.
Even if you were Sherlock Holmes, I would have trouble believing you.
I'd like to shake you by the hand....
Do you want to be arrested for assaulting a policeman?
Huh?
I noticed the Shake n' Shock buzzer concealed in your hand.
Have you any idea what this tool is used for?
Oui, m'sieur. It's a dipstick.
Do you recognize the man in this photograph?
Non, m'sieur, I do not. I have no memory for faces.
Are you certain you don't know this man?
Oui, m'sieur.
I found this tissue.
Aie! What the hell is that?
It's evidence.
Evidence of what? Mayonnaise smuggling?
The sticky stuff is greasepaint.
Ah. And that is supposed to make me happy, is it?
I suggest you think long and hard about what you are doing with your life, m'sieur.
Don't you want this tissue?
No, I do not.
I found this red nose near the café de la Chandelle Verte.
A clown's nose?
That's right.
The guy who wore this is a savage killer.
If you say so, m'sieur.
Don't you want to look at this nose?
Not particularly, m'sieur.
What do you make of this newspaper?
There's a story about a Nobel prize winner from... uh...
Somewhere I can't pronounce.
Yes - and someone has written `Salah-ed Dinn'.
Well, that's a mystery to me.
Nothing.
Take a look at this...
Inspector Rosso's personal card!
Where did you get this?
He gave it to me.
Why?
I think he was impressed with my powers of observation.
He asked me to contact him if I had any information...
Did I show you Rosso's card?
Yes, you did.
I see. You are a grass!
Several hours later I arrived in Ireland, the Emerald Isle.
I'd been lucky to get a bus from Dublin to the tiny village of Lochmarne.
On the way out the driver told me there was only one service a day.
The lad was doing his best to express his adolescent aggression.
His effort was somewhat diminished by the fringe of milk on his lightly feathered upper lip.
It was a featureless plastic box, firmly attached to the wall of the building.
The plastic cover had been smashed and broken away, revealing a switch.
I tugged at the plastic cover, but it didn't move.
I pushed the switch down, but in doing so it snapped off in my hand.
It was impossible to return the switch to its original position.
I tapped the plastic with the lifting key, but it was too strong to shatter.
I tried to flip the switch with the lifting key, but it was much too cumbersome for the job.
The drain was covered with an iron grating, through which I could hear the rush and surge of running water.
The drain was covered with a grating.
I took hold of the grating and pulled hard, but it didn't move.
I tried to use the keys to lever up the grating, but that wasn't going to happen...
Water trickled down the drain, but I couldn't see that I'd achieved anything.
I considered tieing the towel to the grating, but it seemed pointless.
The menu was limited. It read: No Food Today. I didn't care - I'd lost my appetite somewhere over the Irish Sea..

It was a trapdoor in the sidewalk.

It wasn't nerves that stopped me jumping; it was my damned legs. They wouldn't move.
The workman's key was the obvious tool to use to open this trapdoor.
It was specifically designed for a job like this.
Unfortunately, there weren't any holes in the trapdoor.
I was tellin' the truth about Fitzy, Mister!

You can tell me, kid. Is it your dad?
Oh, sir - he drinks! Every last penny - down his evil throat.
An' there's me poor old mother - bed-ridden an' dyin' o' presumption.
I tried to buy her medicine; chopped firewood for Father Mahoney 'til me fingers bled.
The old skinflint cheated me too, but I took the pennies he gave me back home.
Look ma! says I, See what your darlin' son has earnt with his own sweat an' blood!
When suddenly me dad appears an' grabs the loot.
I'm off to Dublin, heavy drinkin', says he. Watch out till I get back!
That's why I runned away.
Something in the grin on his face told me he wasn't being strictly truthful.
He didn't hear me...
You're not telling me you believe in ghosts, are you?
Mister, I seen it with me very own eyes!
Last Tuesday night I went up to see what that dig was about.
I just reached the top o' the wall when I hears this awful noise!
What sort of noise?
A horrible snufflin' and snortin' - like O'Brien's pig, only wurst.
It was comin' from inside the castle!
Did you find out what was making the noise in the castle?
No fear! I just sat dere on the wall like Humpy Dumpy.
The moon was cracked an' greasy like an old dinner plate.
The yard was full o'shadows that could be hidin' anyting.
Did you get to see the ghost?

All gray an' tattered an' hunched over like an old bent willow.

I'm sure there's a rational explanation for what you saw at the castle.
There is - the bloody place is haunted.
Have you seen a guy dressed as a clown?
Here in Lochmarne? They all dress like clowns.

Who are you callin' a kid? I'm twenty-five!
Oh, no - it's twenty-five dat I am. Married, with a car and three kids.
Ten kids, if you count the wife's...

No - it's locked up.

No.
Only...

Break his fingers!

That's right.
Can I have it?
Sorry - I'm keeping this as evidence.

I did. They weren't interested.
You should run tests on that, mister.
You could identify the murderer withe a sample of his snot.

No.
Have you ever seen this man before?
What a slimy character! No - I never seed him.
What do you think this wire could be used for?
Stealin' cars!

The local policeman?
No - nobody in Lochmarne has got a car.

No, I don't. Jewels is for girls.

Smart!

No.
What do you think this tool is used for?
Liftin' drains.

Work experience course at school.

I told you - liftin' drains.

No, sir. I never seed it before in me life.
Do you know what this white powder is?
No.
Give me your hand...
Get lost!

Oh, all right.
Gotcha! Neat, huh?
Didn't feel a thing!
Shake my hand again...
No way!
What does this tissue mean to you?
Nothin'.

I didn't see anything.

Of course.
Thank you.

There was a vacant look on his cow-like face that said quite clearly 'Nobody Home'.
His elbow rested on an obviously soggy piece of towel.

The farmer was drinking and chatting with his pals as if nothing had happened.
Maybe abduction had replaced cattle raiding as a their national pastime...
The guy with the fiddle seemed oblivious to everything except for his playing.
Meanwhile, everyone else in the bar seemed oblivious to him...
The white whiskers on the bartender's flushed face were like garlands on a Christmas tree.
The resemblance ended there. The top of his head was too slick and shiny to act as a perch for a Christmas fairy.
The guy sat in the corner as if he was a permanent fixture.
I'd been taught not to judge people by their appearance or their clothes or the length of their hair...
Nobody ever said anything about runny noses.
I recognized the guy from Maguire's description. He was real twitchy.
The young red-haired guy was plainly nervous about something...
Perhaps he felt threatened by the presence of a handsome dude like me.
It was a beer-stained piece of towelling.
The man's arm lay across the towel, preventing me from moving it.
As the man raised his arm to drink I snatched the towel away.
The end of the bar was hinged, like the drawbridge on a medieval castle...
The glass contained a dark liquid like molasses, with a creamy white froth on the top.
The glass was empty.
I felt strangely compelled to order another, even though my every instinct warned me against it...
It was an electric glass washer. It looked even older than the barman.
I couldn't see anything obviously wrong with the machine. I figured it must be the wiring.
The glass washer was sloshing and bubbling like an old man in a jacuzzi.
The glass washer was lifeless. Hardly surprising as it didn't have a supply of electricity.
Touching the glass washer would have been like putting my hand in a blender...
There was nothing physically wrong with the glass washer.
It was an electrical plug attached to the glass washer.
It seemed fine to me.
I looked at the plug I'd fixed and felt a glow of pride. All my own work!
I replaced the fuse with the piece of wire.
I knew it was dangerous, but I was desperate enough to disregard everything I knew about standard safety precautions.
It was an electric pump, operated by pushing a small lever.
I was about to reach for the pump when I came to my senses
A rash move like that in a strange country with strange customs could be my last!
There was an old fish with skin like leather in the cabinet. It looked like it'd been dead for a while.
The cabinet was out of reach. That old fish was washed up high and dry.
It was a short piece of wire, twisted into a rough circle.
As I stared at the circle of wire, the old man snatched it away and put it in his coat.
Almost as if he'd sensed my intentions, the old derelict snatched the wire from the table.
As soon as the old guy looked away I grabbed his piece of wire.
It was a telephone, incongruous in the rustic setting of the homely bar.
Hi! My name's Stobbart - George Stobbart.
Hey!
Hello dere, mister. What can I do for you?
Hello dere again, mister.
What's got into Fitzgerald?
He's a very confused man...
So am I. It's not like him to be shoutin' his mouth off like dat.
He wasn't listening...
Can I buy you a drink?
You most certainly can!
Give me a drink for my friend here.
Who? Doyle? Has he conned you into buying for him?
Shame on you, Patrick! Same again?
Just a pint this time, Michael.
Can you tell me anything about the castle on the hill?
Oh, I don't know much about anyting!
You should ask Mr. O'Brien here - he does joined-up writing.
Would you be one o' dem history fellas yourself?
That's right! Professor Stobbart, Miskatonic University.
You're an archaeologist? And you're asking us about the castle?
Excuse me, Mister O'Brien! D' gentleman was talkin' t' me!
I thought you said you were a reporter?
Yeah, I am, but I studied to be an archaeologist.
Oh, no - I'm an archaeologist.
I'm researching the story of Lochmarne Castle for a scientific journal.
Oh, I see!
How come you didn't leave with d' others?
I didn't know they'd gone until the landlord told me.
I didn't know they'd gone!
Oh, yes. Packed dere spades and shovels and away dey went.
Seems I missed all the excitement!
What excitement?
Professor Peagram's discovery!
Haven't you heard?
No?
Oh, no. I'm here on vacation.
What's dat?
A vacation, Pat. It's what the Americans call a holiday.
But he's lying to you, anyhow. He told me he's a journalist.
Oh. What's wrong wid dat?
Journalists are mostly scum, Pat.
What? Even Clark Kent? I can't believe it!
Oh, right. In Lochmarne? You come to Lochmarne for a holiday?
Sure. It's a very pretty place.
Where d' hell are you from, mister?
California.
Ha-ha. Yeah... amongst other things.
No, I don't.
I mean, I know who he is, but I don't know him to talk to.
Where has Peagram gone?
He's disappeared! Gone! Skedaddled!
And... nobody knows where he's gone!
Except you...?
No, I don't know either.
Do you know anything about Peagram's excavation?
Only dat he didn't have d' right tools for d' job.
What he needed was shovels and a J.C.B.!
Peagram was digging for historical remains, not coal.
Is dat a fact? What d' hell for?
It's the science of archaeology, Pat.
Understanding how people used to live by what they've left behind.
One day archaeologists might be digging up OUR remains.
Imagine dat, Mister O'Brien! I wonder what dey'll find?
Well, it won't be arrow-heads and beakers.
Fast food cartons and flavored condoms, more likely.
Did anyone from the village work at Peagram's dig?
I tried it meself, but dat high-an'-mighty history man called me incontinent!
What a nerve! Hadn't I dug more holes dan d' rest o' dem put togedder?
Do you remember seeing Sean Fitzgerald at the dig?
Hmm... Let me see, now...
I tink me brainbox needs a spot o'lubrication.
Do you remember Sean Fitzgerald now?
I can picture d' scene as if it was only last week.
Come to think of it, it WAS only last week.
Fitzgerald was dere all right, him an' a bunch o' students.
He was speakin' wid the boss man.
Aren't you going to help Fitzgerald?
What does he need my help for?
Didn't you hear what Maguire said? He's been hit by a car!
What an idiot! People call me stupid, but I've never done that.
Don't you feel any sympathy for poor Fitzgerald?
He never bothered about me, so why should I?
Is it true that Peagram found a valuable gem?
What? First I heard of it!
Take no notice of that fella, Pat. He's a journalist.
Where have you been, Pat?
That gem is the talk of every town from Lochmarne to Ballydoon.
Nobody told me! The lucky sod! So that's why he's scampered...
Do you know anything about the Knights Templar?
And who might dey be?
A bunch of guys from way back in the times of the Crusades.
Ah, history never was me best subject.
Father Mahoney never taught you history!
You were thrown out for disrupting the class.
I know, I know! But if he had it wouldn'a bin me best subject.
How can you learn about sometin' that happened when you wasn't dere?
I never heard o'their likes before you brought them up.
Have you heard o' these knights, Mister O'Brien?
Ah, sure - I read about them in the Reader's Digest.
A fascinating article on their revolutionary financial methods.
Christ! History's not what it used to be.
What do you know about leprechauns, Doyle?
Leprechauns! Is it d' liddle people you're talkin' about?
Sure and a cousin o' mine was wed to one.
Oh, come on! Do you really expect me to believe that?
It's d' truth I'm tellin' you. She fell asleep on a fairy ring, see?
When she woke up there he was, a liddle fella, all in green!
Tell me more about your cousin and the leprechaun...
Oh, no...
Well, young Mary was speechless - especially when the leprechaun up and spoke to her!
Be my bride me darlin' says he, an' you'll never want for riches again.
Okay, says she, an' he slips a ring o' daisies on her finger.
Amen.
So there y'are - proof that d' liddle people exist!
That's no proof! All you have is her word for it!
Not so - the followin' spring she had a liddle baby!
Did the leprechaun's promise come true?
What promise was that, now?
That she'd never want for riches again.
Now there's the strangest thing. She never did!
I thought you said she was claiming the social, Pat?
Indeed, Mister O'Brien, but there's riches and riches...
She told me - Pat, she says, that liddle darlin' boy is all the riches in d' world t' me!
Oh, nothing really.
'Bye for now...
What do you think of this towel?
Now there's a fine piece of cloth if ever I did see one!
I found it on the bar, under your elbow.
I thought it looked familiar.
Look at this towel...
You showed me that before.
What does this false nose mean to you?
Ah, now - you're a clown.
No, not me...
Ah! You're a good one, aren't ya?
Did you hear that, Michael?
I hate clowns.
Ha! Listen to this fella! I hate clowns, says he.
Isn't he just the funniest man you ever did see, Michael?
He's not a clown, Doyle.
He's not even remotely funny.
Thanks.
Have you seen this nose before?
Yes, mister.
Before I showed it to you the first time, I mean.
Uh... when was that?
Never mind.
No, sir. Definitely not.
Do you recognize the man in this photograph?
It's a handsome mug on that fella, to be sure. Is he a film star?
Don't be fooled - this is the face of a psychopathic killer!
No! Well, there's one in the eye for me and my mouth!
Are you sure you haven't seen this man?
It's the face of a therapeutic killer.
Oh, never mind...
Does this piece of wire mean anything to you?
Not me, mister.
Do you recognize this gem?
Saints be praised! It must be worth a fortune!
Maybe it is. Have you seen it before?
It's the one which Peagram took from the dig.
Oh. How come you've got it now?
He left it behind. I'm looking after it.
Oh. You could take that to Dublin an' sell it.
Yes - you showed me before.
Does this security pass mean anything to you?
Uh... hmmm. Well... no.
What do you make of this tool?
It's for lifting manhole covers.
That's right! I, uh... found it in Paris.
Will you look at that! A French sewer key. Marvellous!
Do you recognize this matchbook?
No.
Do you recognise this white powder?
No, I don't.
May I shake your hand...?
No, you can't.
How come?
Because I'll spill my beer if you do.
Does this tissue mean anything to you?
No, but you should show that to my granny.
She could tell your fortune from it.
From a soiled tissue?
Sure! Some people read tea-leaves - my granny reads handkerchiefs.
No, boss.
What do you think of this flashlight?
It's not very bright, is it?
I could say the same about some of the present company...
That's true. But don't let him hear you.
Keep it under your hat, mister.
That flashlight, like your brain Doyle, is not switched on.
I don't think he heard me.
You showed me before, mister.
Hello!
He was engrossed in conversation with the other men...
Ah, hello there. Let me introduce you to my pals...
We've already met.
What now?
I want you to know you have my sympathy...
Oh, it's just terrible! Awful!
It's the worst news I heard all day.
It's topped the bad news all right, for this week and the next.
The whole year...
It's worse than that - it's the worst disaster in living memory!
Isn't it the biggest calamity in the history of the village?
I would say it's the biggest in the history of Ireland!
The most awesome disaster since mankind paddled out of the primal plop...
There's no beer.
I dare say I'll get over it...
What about Sean? Why aren't you out looking for him?
There's no point in launching an ill-equipped expedition to save the lad.
In a life or death situation, preparation is essential.
That's why I slipped in here.
For a pint.
Is a glass of beer more important than a man's life!?
Were you talking to me?
To all of you! Sean Fitzgerald has met with god-knows-what, and all you can do is drink!
Sean has gone for a ride in a flash car, that's all.
Why don't you calm down and join us?
I gotta go...
Do you know anything about this piece of wire?
It looks like a hand made snare.
Do you have any use for this towel?
I suppose I could squeeze it out into my glass if I was desperate enough...
Does this false nose mean anything to you?
You're a circus clown.
No, but I got this from someone who disguised himself as a clown.
Is that a fact? Why did he do that now?
He's a psychotic killer. I think he may be connected with Peagram's disappearance.
Do I show you this nose?
Yes, you did.
Do you recognise the name on this card?
I can't read that little writing!
It says: `Thomas Moerlin, Grüber Electronics.'
Is that your name? Tommy Merlin?
No...
But what a great stage name! It had what my high-school hypnosis act had lacked: style and class!
For a few seconds I bathed in spot lights on a thundering tide of applause: Tommy Merlin, Hypnotist!
Are you all right?
I'm fine. I just remembered something...
About this pass...
You showed me before.
This is the gem that Peagram found in the castle...
So that's what all the fuss was about...
And that's where it belongs!
Do you recognise the man in this photograph?
No, but I wouldn't trust him. His eyes are too close together.
He's not a friend of yours, is he?
Oh, no. Far from it. In fact, I believe it's the face of a killer!
I knew it! Piggy eyes. Can't trust 'em.
I already told you I didn't.
Does this tool mean anything to you?
No, it doesn't. Is it used on sheep?
Never! How?
They'd slip out. Angles all wrong... You'd never do it.
I have! I did it in Paris.
You already showed me that, and I wasn't impressed.
What do you make of this matchbook?
Seems ordinary enough to me.
Would you like to shake my hand?
What is this? I don't do that male bonding stuff!
Come on - forget your prejudice and shake hands...
Never. It's not natural.
What do you think of my flashlight?
Those electric lamps are useful, but limited in lifespan, in my experience.
I was given one for my birthday, but it stopped working after a month.
The battery was probably drained.
What? Nobody told me! I threw it away!
Did I show you my flashlight?
Indeed you did.
What do you make of this tissue?
That is a very unpleasant object indeed.
Excuse me!
Excuse me, Mr Leary!
I fixed your glass washer, no problem.
Bingo, and a blessing to all the saints!
A free half pint to that man, on the house!
Now - could you take a look at the beer pumps?
I guess so, but I'm not making any promises...
If you can't fix them I'll have a riot on my hands!
The pumps are in the cellar, right?
That's right. You'll find a flashlight down there somewhere...
Hey! Where do you think you're going?
Excuse me?
No customers behind the bar! Ever!
Get out!
I could try to fix your glass washer.
Oh, no - not unless you're a qualified electrician...
Don't change the subject!
Are you gonna pay me Peagram's rent or not?
No way!
Listen - I'm not really his friend. I've never even met the guy!
I need to find Peagram - urgently. I think his life is in danger.
Damn right it is!
Excuse me for butting in, Michael, but I think the young fella's telling the truth.
I'm sorry I bit your head off, sir.
That's okay. I understand... I guess.
Top of the morning to you!
I beg your pardon?
That's what you Irish say, isn't it?
Do you want something or are you just flaunting your xenophobia?
Unh... I was trying to be sociable.
Hmph! Is it a room you're after?
No, thank you. I don't plan to stay too long.
Who does? Most folk take one look at Lochmarne and jump back on the bus.
That's not a bad idea. Do you have a vacancy?
I could, if you don't mind waiting until the last guest checks out.
No problem. When will that be?
When the undertaker comes to collect him.
What did you say to get rid of Fitzgerald?
Uh... it was a... misunderstanding.
I've never seen him move so fast.
I could use your help at closing time, clearing the bar!
Yes, sir?
He hadn't heard me...
Well?
Well what?
Are you going to fix this glass washer or not?
What?
I'm still waiting for you to fix this glass washer!
Okay! Keep your hair on!
A glass of beer, please.
I'll try a glass of beer, please.
Is this your first pint of 'real ale'?
Beer that's brewed from natural ingredients to traditional methods.
It shouldn't be kept under pressure, or refrigerated.
And finally, it should have a good body and distinctive character.
In other words, it's flat and warm with bits in and it makes you fall over.
May I have another beer, please?
Certainly, sir! Same again?
That's the secret of the master brewers, sir!
Each barrel is lovingly manhandled in time-honored fashion...
Suspended on skillfully tied ropes of the finest hemp...
Lowered into the cellar utilising the forces of original gravity.
Like manna from heaven!
Hey, how about another drink!
Same again?
Hmm,,, Do you serve cocktails?
I'll serve anyone with manners and money.
I'm serious. Have you considered turning MacDevitts into a cocktail bar?
What? Kids in the bar?! Can you imagine it?
Pinball, pimples and puke!
Gimme another beer, dude!
Give EVERYONE another beer! Let's PARTY, guys!
I think you've had enough, don't you?
Hey, listen - is it supposed to taste the way it does?
More beer, over here!
Yes, sir.
I'm sorry, but the pump appears to be broken!
I could fix it for you!
I don't think so. This is a job for a professional electrician.
Oh well, at least the glass washer is still working...
It's not my day, is it?
What can you tell me about the castle?
You're the second person to ask me that today!
I don't know anything about the castle.
It's only an old ruin anyway.
Who else was asking about the castle?
He said he was a reporter.
He was askin' about the little people!
I could have told him a tale or two about d' liddle people.
He might have paid me to hear what he wanted me to say.
Anyway, I chucked him out on his arse.
Good for you, Mick! That's the way to deal with journalists!
Have you served any, uh... clowns recently?
No, you're the first today.
Seriously - I'm looking for a man dressed in a clown costume.
Would he be having a little white dog with a black patch over the eye?
I shouldn't think so.
What?
Do you know a man called Peagram?
Indeed I do!
Are you a friend of his, by any chance?
In a manner of speaking, I am.
Right, me boyo! A hundred and sixty quid he owes me! Pay up!
That's Peagram's business, not mine.
Ah, but he's done a bunk, hasn't he? Scampered!
I know. That's why I'm here. To look for him.
And what about the money he owes me?
When I find him, I'll remind him about it.
Oh, no. I'm just trying to track him down.
Me too! That son of a bitch should be locked away!
Did Peagram stay here?
Yes, he did! Six nights - plus breakfast.
He couldn'a had breakfast dis morning, not unless he had it afore he went to bed!
What the hell are you talking about, Doyle?
D' history fella - I seen him dis morning, crack o' dawn.
I had t' get up at four o' clock, t' see to d' missus.
I didn't know your wife was sick, Pat!
She's not. Anyhow - I went out to empty d' bucket, and what d'you think I saw?
For the love o' God, Doyle - get to the point!
It was d' history man, headin' out o' d' village - on a bicycle!
I knew it! Hand over my money, or I'll throw you out!
That's right - in the best room in the house.
Dat's d' one wid d' bed.
Can I see Peagram's room?
It's been taken by one of the brothers from the reformatory.
They come every year for spiritual refreshment.
Dat's a good one! Dere idea of refreshment is a gutful of stout!
I wouldn't want to disturb a man of God.
Especially not a big fella from the bad boys' home.
I don't blame you, Mick. Dat brother's got muscles like a muscle-man!
About Fitzgerald...
I'm looking for a man named Fitzgerald.
Fitzy? What's he done?
I believe he may have worked at Peagram's dig.
Sean Fitzgerald? WORK? You've got the wrong guy!
Do you know Sean Fitzgerald very well?
I know him enough not to sell him more than two pints.
He's like a kid when he gets a few beers inside him.
I'm not surprised - he's on medication. For his nerves.
There's nothing wrong with his nerves! He's just screwy.
Aren't you going to see what happened to Fitzgerald?
Why?
D... didn't you hear what the kid said?
The man's been hit by an automobile!
You don't want to listen to Maguire. He's a born liar, and a hooligan!
I'm really concerned for Fitzgerald's safety!
Why? He's probably gone home, unless he's in the ditch.
Don't you care about him? He was real uptight when he left the bar!
And whose fault was that? YOU were talking to him, not me.
That's right, Michael.
It's not wrong you are dere, Mister O'Brien.
Now just a minute, you guys! All I did was ask him about Peagram.
That fella owes me a hundred and eighty quid!
That's a awful lot of money, Michael.
With compound interest, too. It grows with each time o' telling...
Look, I gotta be going...
I don't want anything.
Just give me a shout when you do...
Thanks...
I found your flashlight.
So I see. You'd better keep hold of that until you've fixed the pumps.
Do you recognize this man?
No, I don't. What d'you want with him?
I've got a score to settle...
I don't want any trouble in the bar, mister.
If it's a fight you're looking for, see Father Mahoney.
A priest? A man of the cloth?
Sure, and he teaches the boys how to box at the youth club.
According to Mahoney, it develops character.
Isn't that right, Pat? Didn't he teach you the art of pugilism?
Doyle!
Sorry, Michael. I was miles away. What did you say?
Ah, never mind.
You already asked me that.
Does this false nose mean anything to you?
It's not red nose day again, is it?
I know that! Good god almighty, what d'you take me for?
And before you ask, I haven't seen any clowns in the bar.
No, it doesn't!
Does this piece of wire mean anything to you?
Good god, man - put it away!
What's the problem?
Don't play the innocent with me, mister!
What you do with that wire is your own business, but don't drag me into it!
No, it doesn't.
Here's something which might interest you...
Huh? What is it?
My passport to the sewers of Paris.
Is that so?
Did you see the snooker last night, Mr. O'Brien?
I haven't got a television, Michael.
I take it no-one wants to hear about my underground escapades?
It doesn't.
Do you recognize this matchbook?
No, sir.
Does this...
I knew it! The minute you walked through the door I knew you spelled trouble!
Now just a minute!
It might be what you're used to in New York, but we don't use that stuff here!
Hey, it's plaster! I found it in the castle!
I'm not interested.
Shake my hand...
Hey, bartender!
Landlord, if y' don't mind.
Sorry. Shake my hand, why don't you...
Now why should I do that? What have you got up your sleeve?
Nothing! C'mon, just shake my hand...
Not just now, mister. I have t' be careful on account o' the health restrictions.
Aw, jeez!
Why won't you shake my hand?
Because I don't know where you've been.
Do you recognize the name on this card?
No - should I?
Are you sure you don't recognize this...
I told you - no!
It just so happens I'm an electrician! Check out my credentials..
Well, now, isn't that marvelous?
Here's a house bedeviled with faulty wiring of a wayward nature...
Here's you, an electric man - with a little plastic card t' prove it!
You can make a start on the glass washer.
When you've finished that will you take a look at the pumps...?
Check out my card...
I've seen it, for heaven's sake!
May I borrow this towel?
Sure you can, on one condition...
What's that?
You keep it away from old Ron.
Who's Ron?
That's him in the corner - with the hygiene problem.
You can keep it.
Does this gem mean anything to you?
Phew! What a beauty! I bet you wish that was real, don't you?
Does this tissue mean anything to you?
That's disgusting!
Uh-huh! I found it in the sewers
What's the idea of waving it around in my face?
You're worse than old Ron! Put it away, man!
No, it doesn't.
Hey! I just seen a big red...
Get out of here, Maguire!
Come back when you're old enough!
What's the lad howling about?
A big red sports car!
Sean Fitzgerald's been runned over!
Get OUT!
Noisy little tyke.
Maybe you should send out some medicinal brandy, Michael...
Oh, yes! And who's going to pay for it?
Not me!
Me too, neither!
Hello, there! My name's George Stobbart.
Excuse me, mister O'Brien...
Pleased to meet you I'm sure. I'm O'Brien. Can I help you?
What now?
Hello, there. What now?
Young Fitzgerald seems to have a problem...
Uh... yeah. I don't know what got into him.
He's a strange lad. Gets wrapped up inside himself.
He wasn't listening...
What can you tell me about the castle, Mr O'Brien?
Ah, you're wasting your time.
There's no story there - just a pile of rock and rubble.
It's a fine sight now, isn't it?
Dates back to the tenth century, you know.
Most of the existing building was added much later, of course.
Are the ruins open to the public?
Oh, no - it's much too dangerous.
Anyway there's nothing of interest remaining.
Peagram thought otherwise didn't he?
Ah, but it's not difficult to get them history boys excited is it?
Give them a bone to play with and they're happy as puppies.
Can you tell me about the tripod which was found at the castle?
Now there's a bone of contention and controversy.
It was dug up by an Englishman of the archaeological persuasion.
Who was this Englishman?
Professor Peagram. The same man who dug up the gem...
Was it Peagram who dug up the tripod at the castle?
The same man if he wasn't his twin brother.
And can you guess what he did with the tripod?
He sent it to a museum in Paris. I've seen it.
How can I get into the castle?
Those walls were built specifically to stop people getting in, Mr Stobbart.
But I dare say you'll find a way, if you've the will...
Listen, it's closed, locked, barred and bolted.
The castle is as impenetrable as the walls of Troy.
So I can't get in, then?
My, you're bright for a journalist!
Have you heard of the Phantom?
More than that - I've seen it!
And let me tell you - it's a dreadful spectacle!
So it's not just a local legend?
There really IS a Phantom of Lochmarne?
Oh, no.
I was talking about the Phantom of the Opera.
What can you tell me about the gem which Peagram found?
Now there is a gem which should never have been taken.
A man would have to be full of greed to covet that stone.
What's your interest in the jewel? You're not a reporter, are you?
Yes, that's right.
Another bloody news hound...! Well, you're wasting your time here, boy.
You'll find the people of Lochmarne are a tight-lipped and cautious lot.
Why? Have you got something to hide?
It's just that we don't like to wash our dirty laundry in public.
Oh, no.
Thank the lord for that.
The boy told me Fitzgerald was driven away in the car that hit him.
Maguire is always spinning wild yarns.
I don't know where he gets them from. Television, I expect, or comics.
If I was you, I'd take what he says with a generous pinch of salt.
Maguire's tale about the car sounds quite plausible to me.
He says the driver was dressed like a leprechaun!
That boy has a head full of fluffy toys!
You're too late to meet that fella.
Is he dead?
Not that - but he's gone from the village.
A sore point with our esteemed host, I might add!
Why don't you leave the poor man alone?
I just want to talk to him.
Hound him to death, more likely!
You news boys are all the same.
Do you know where Peagram has gone?
Haven't I made it clear enough to you?
I don't like parasites or things that crawl, and that includes journalists.
I'm sorry but I don't.
He upped anchor in the dark and shipped out before the dawn.
Why did he do that?
Who knows? A guilty conscience, or a secret assignation...
Whatever the reason he'll not be missed in Lochmarne.
Maybe now the fuss about the gem has died down we can get back to normal.
Why has Peagram's departure upset the landlord?
He's lost a paying guest, that's why.
More than that - there's the question of an unsettled bill.
Poor Michael's seen red over the business, and I don't blame him.
Well, why don't you ask him yourself, mister Ace-reporter?
Can you tell me more about the landlord?
Mick Leary? He's what you call a would-be sophisticate.
The trouble is, his idea of sophistication extends as far as putting paper in the lavatory.
I never worked out why he did dat.. It's much too dark in dere to read.
That's true. Have you ever run your hand over the back of the door?
The graffiti is written in braille.
What's your game? Keep your nose out of our business, mister!
Do you know Sean Fitzgerald?
Yes, I do.
What do you want with him?
I want to talk to him about working at the dig.
What makes you think he did?
The boy outside told me.
I can't imagine anyone employing Sean Fitzgerald on a dig.

I placed the cog and spindle back in the supporting frame.

The demon's face was complete, and the effect chilled me to the bone.

There was a simple reason: the demon didn't have any eyes.
I ran my fingers across the cold stone and probed the holes in the demon's eyes.

The cog turned freely, but nothing happened.
I tried turning the cogs but couldn't move them. I needed a mechanical advantage.
I pushed the handle into the demon's mouth - the cogs all meshed. I began to turn...

With a rasp of metal on stone I eased the second eye into place.

...but the reflection has three hideous faces.
